Fig. 1 (A) The 29Si MAS NMR spectra of (a) NH2-MCM-41 and (b) NH2-(CH3)MCM-41. (B) XRD patterns and (C) N2 adsorption–desorption isotherms with the corresponding pore size distribution (inset) of (a) NH2-MCM-41, (b) ImPy-MCM-41, (c) 3.4%Cu-ImPy-MCM-41, (d) 0.94%Pd-ImPy-MCM-41, (e) 3.2% Cu/0.89% Pd-ImPy-MCM-41, (f) 3.2% Cu-0.87% Pd-ImPy-MCM-41, and (g) 0.86% Pd-3.2% Cu-ImPy-MCM-41. (D) TEM images of 0.86% Pd-3.2% Cu-ImPy-MCM-41. (E) FT-IR spectra of (a) NH2-MCM-41, (b) ImPy-MCM-41, (c) 3.4%Cu-ImPy-MCM-41, (d) 0.94%Pd-ImPy-MCM-41, (e) 3.2% Cu/0.89% Pd-ImPy-MCM-41, (f) 3.2% Cu-0.87% Pd-ImPy-MCM-41, and (g) 0.86% Pd-3.2% Cu-ImPy-MCM-41. (F) UV–Vis DRS spectra of (a) ImPy-MCM-41, (b) 0.94%Pd-ImPy-MCM-41, (c) 3.4% Cu-ImPy-MCM-41, (d) 3.2% Cu/0.89% Pd-ImPy-MCM-41, (e) 3.2% Cu-0.87% Pd-ImPy-MCM-41, and (f) 0.86% Pd-3.2% Cu-ImPy-MCM-41. Fig. 2 STEM mapping images of Cu, Pd, and their overlay for (a) 3.2% Cu-0.87% Pd-ImPy-MCM-41, (b) 0.86% Pd-3.2% Cu-ImPy-MCM-4, and (c) 3.2% Cu/0.89% Pd-ImPy-MCM-41. Fig. 3 XPS spectra of Cu2p (left) and Pd3d (right) for (a) 3.4% Cu-ImPy-MCM-41 (left) or 0.94% Pd-ImPy-MCM-41 (right), (b) 3.2% Cu/0.89% Pd-ImPy-MCM-41, (c) 3.2% Cu-0.87% Pd-ImPy-MCM-41, and (d) 0.86% Pd-3.2% Cu-ImPy-MCM-4. Fig. 4 FT-IR spectra of (A) ethanol adsorption/desorption and (B) CO adsorption/desorption at 30 °C on (a) 3.4%Cu-ImPy-MCM-41, (b) 0.94%Pd-ImPy-MCM-41 and (c) 0.86% Pd-3.2% Cu-ImPy-MCM-41. Fig. 5 FT-IR spectra of CO adsorption after ethanol adsorption at 30 °C on (A) 0.86%Pd-3.2%Cu-ImPy-MCM-41, (B) 3.2%Cu-0.87%Pd-ImPy-MCM-41, and (C) 3.2%Cu/0.89%Pd-ImPy-MCM-41. (D) The intensity ratio of 2095 (2094) cm−1 (CO on Cu (I) sites) to 2978 cm−1 (C-H stretching mode of adsorbed ethanol). Fig. 6 Profiles of product selectivity and ethanol conversion with time on stream over 0.86 %Pd-3.2%Cu-ImPy-MCM-41: (a) as-prepared, (b) pre-treated with CO for 2 h, (c) pre-treated with ethanol for 2 h, and (d) pre-treated with CO and ethanol for 2 h. Reaction conditions: 350 mg of catalyst; 130 °C; 1.5 MPa; CO, 80 sccm; O2, 7 sccm; LHSV = 8.57 mL∙gcat −1∙h−1. The line and dot in black stands for DEC, violet for diethyl ether, dark yellow for acetaldehyde, blue for ethyl formate, green for DEE, magenta for diethyl oxalate, and red for sum of carbonylation. Fig. 7 DRIFTS spectra of ethanol adsorption/desorption on 0.86%Pd-3.2%Cu-ImPy-MCM-41 at 130 °C under (a) Ar flow, (b) CO flow, (c) O2 flow, and (d) CO and O2 flow for 15 min. Fig. 8 Operando DRIFTS spectra for ethanol oxycarbonylation on (A) 3.2%Cu/0.89%Pd-ImPy-MCM-41, (B) 3.2%Cu-0.87%Pd-ImPy-MCM-41, and (C) 0.86%Pd-3.2%Cu-ImPy-MCM-41. (D) The intensity ratio of 1680 (1678) cm−1 (C = O stretching mode of the formed carboethoxide intermediate) to 1279 (1271, or 1263) cm−1 (C-H stretching mode of adsorbed ethanol). Cu-Pd pair facilitated simultaneous activation of ethanol and CO Jian Zhang Yazhe Zhang Jieqiong Zhao Zhe An Yanru Zhu Xin Shu Hongyan Song Xu Xiang Xiaodan Ma Jing He ⁎ State Key Laboratory of Chemical Resource Engineering & Beijing Advanced Innovation Center for Soft Matter Science and Engineering, Beijing University of Chemical Technology, Beijing 100029, China State Key Laboratory of Chemical Resource Engineering & Beijing Advanced Innovation Center for Soft Matter Science and Engineering Beijing University of Chemical Technology Beijing 100029 China State Key Laboratory of Chemical Resource Engineering & Beijing Advanced Innovation Center for Soft Matter Science and Engineering, Beijing University of Chemical Technology, Beijing 100029, China ⁎ Corresponding author at: Box 98, 15 Beisanhuan Donglu, Beijing 100029, China. Box 98 15 Beisanhuan Donglu Beijing 100029 China Graphical abstract Oxidative carbonylation has attracted broad interest from both academia and industry in recent years. Oxycarbonylation of ethanol to diethyl carbonate (DEC) has been of great challenge due to the difficulty in the simultaneous activation of ethanol and CO. This work reports a heterogeneous Cu-Pd pair catalysis for simultaneous activation of ethanol and CO, affording a selectivity of 85.4% to DEC and a space–time yield (STY) of up to 207 mg∙g−1∙h−1. Well distributed Cu-Pd pair affords more Cu (I) sites, promoting CO activation and the followed insertion to adsorbed ethanol. Further increasing ratio of Cu (I) species via the pre-treatment of catalyst with CO and ethanol promotes simultaneously the activation of ethanol and CO, affording a STY of 325 mg∙g−1∙h−1 of DEC. Keywords Ethanol conversion Oxycarbonylation Cu-Pd pair Diethyl carbonate 1 Introduction Carbonylation reactions, such as formylation [1], oxycarbonylation [2], hydroformylation [3], alkoxycarbonylation [4], aminocarbonylation [5], carbonylative Heck [6], Suzuki-Miyaura coupling [7] and Sonogashira coupling [8], have been recognized as versatile tool to convert various bulk chemicals into an extensive set of useful products, including ketones [9], aldehydes [10], amides [11], esters [12], and other carboxylic acid derivatives [13], which have been used in industry to create pharmaceuticals, agrochemicals and their intermediates [14]. Oxycarbonylation of alcohols, involving the insertion of CO and construction of C-O bonds, provides a sustainable and economical way to produce carbonates [15]. Applying ethanol as the substrate in the oxycarbonylation to produce diethyl carbonate (DEC) [16] has drawn arising attention due to the wide sources and easy production of ethanol from renewable biomass [17–19]. DEC has wide application in synthetic chemistry, including as raw materials for polycarbonates [16], bio-active compounds [20], and fluorescent compounds [21]. DEC has also been directly applied as electrolyte in lithium ion batteries [22,23], fuel additive [15], and excellent solvent [15,24] for synthetic resin and cellulose ether. DEC was industrially produced via phosgenation of ethanol [25], trans-esterification [25], alcoholysis of urea [26], carbonylation of ethyl nitrite [27], and ethanol oxycarbonylation [28]. As revealed by previous studies on direct oxycarbonylation of methanol, the oxycarbonylation of alcohols involves oxidation of alcohols to alkoxide groups, insertion of CO to form carbo-alkoxide species, and the followed reaction of carbo-alkoxide species with alcohol [29–31]. Simultaneously, the catalyst goes through a reduction–oxidation process [29–32]. There exist great challenges in that an effective oxycarbonylation of alcohol requires simultaneous activation of CO and alcohol on one or adjacent active sites. Cu (I) or Cu (II) is well-known catalyst for oxycarbonylation of alcohols. CuCl was first used in 1983 for oxycarbonylation of methanol to DMC in liquid-phase system [28]. At the end of 1980s, gas-phase oxycarbonylation was established by applying CuCl2 or Cu complex supported on activated carbon (AC) [33]. Later, many efforts have been dedicated to improving oxycarbonylation efficacy. One effective strategy is tailoring of the electronic properties of active sites. Incorporation of N ligands, including Schiff bases, has been used to modulate the coordination environment of active sites, thus promoting the oxycarbonylation of ethanol in liquid-phase system [34,35]. Coordinating CuCl with 1,10-phenanthroline and N-methyl imidazole gives an ethanol conversion of 15.2% and a DEC selectivity of 99.0%, higher than on bare CuCl (3.9% conversion and 98.6% selectivity) [34]. In a gas-phase system by using supported-type catalyst, the structure of active sites [36], surface oxygenated group of carbon support [37,38], the interactions between supports and active sites [39], or the dispersion of active sites [38–41], have been found to affect the oxycarbonylation activity of methanol. A STY of DMC of up to 290.5 mg∙g−1∙h−1 with a selectivity of 59.4% to DMC has been achieved on CuCl2/AC due to the formation of Cu-Cl-OH [36]. The surface oxygenated groups not only influence the dispersion but also the valence distribution of copper species, and a STY of DMC of 229 mg∙g−1∙h−1 and a methanol conversion of 9.2% in 10 h have been afforded with copper supported on AC treated with HNO3 [38]. Introducing a second component, such as Pd, which has been widely used in the oxidative carbonylation reactions [32], has also been applied to promote the efficiency of oxycarbonylation, which is especially necessary and effective for the oxycarbonylation of ethanol [42–48]. About 9.5% yield of DEC has been obtained on CuCl2-PdCl2/AC, 2.2 times higher than that on CuCl2/AC [42]. Pd2+ plays an important role in increasing the yield of DEC [42,43]. Further treatment of CuCl2-PdCl2/AC with base, such as hydroxides [42,43], CH3COOK [44], or NaOH/KCl [45,46], significantly enhances the oxycarbonylation of alcohols due to the formed Cu2Cl(OH)3 or Cu(OH)Cl bonded with PdCl2. The electron transfer between Cu2+/Cu+ and Pd0/Pd2+ has been found to be beneficial to DMC yield. About 18% yield of DEC was afforded on CuCl2-PdCl2-KOH/AC [43]. Treating CuCl2-PdCl2/HMS with quaternary ammonium salts not only facilitates the formation of Cu+ species but also promotes the dispersion of Cu+ species [48]. A STY of 210.9 g∙L−1∙h−1 for DEC has been produced with PdCl2-CuCl2-TEAB/HMS [48], much higher than a STY of 90 g∙L−1∙h−1 on PdCl2-CuCl2/HMS. Here this work reports an efficient heterogeneous Cu-Pd catalyst, in which an effective Cu-Pd pair has been fabricated by modulating the coordination sequence of Cu (II) and Pd (II) precursor onto imine pyridine modified surface of mesoporous silica. In the oxycarbonylation of ethanol to DEC, a space–time yield (STY) of up to 207 mg∙g−1∙h−1 to DEC and a selectivity of 85.4% to DEC have been achieved. The high STY of DEC is primarily ascribed to Cu-Pd interactions and the generated more Cu (I) sites, which facilitates the simultaneous activation of ethanol and CO and also the followed CO insertion. The ability for CO insertion can be further improved by pre-activating the catalyst, with a STY of 325 mg∙g−1∙h−1 to DEC afforded. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Materials Tetraethyl orthosilicate (TEOS) was purchased from Alfa Aesar and hexadecyltrimethylammonium bromide (CTAB) from Innochem Scientific& Technology Ltd. Tetramethylammonium hydroxide (TMAOH), 3-aminopropyl triethoxysilane (APS), trimethylmethoxysilane, 2-pyridinecarboxaldehyde, and palladium chloride (PdCl2) were purchased from J&K Scientific Ltd. CuCl2·2H2O and toluene were purchased from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co. Ltd. Anhydrous methanol and ethanol were purchased from Aladdin. All of the reagents are of analytical purity and used without further purification except toluene. Toluene was dewatered under nitrogen atmosphere to afford hydrous toluene. 2.2 Preparation NH2-Mesoporous Crystalline Material-41 (NH2-MCM-41) and MCM-41: NH2-MCM-41 was prepared via direct co-condensation method according to the reported procedure [49]. Typically, CTAB (0.0104 mol, 3.79 g) was dissolved in deionized water (200 g) at room temperature. After stirring for 1 h, TMAOH (0.0312 mol, 5.65 g) was added, followed by the addition of TEOS (0.078 mol, 16.25 g). After stirring for 1 h, 8.67 mmol of APS was added. The suspension was stirred vigorously for 2 h at ambient temperature and then kept statically in a Teflon autoclave at 100 °C for 72 h. The solid was filtered, washed with deionized water for 5 times and with ethanol for the last time, and dried overnight at 80 °C, and extracted by ethanol at 60 °C for 3 times (6 h each time) to remove CTAB. Similar procedure was used, except without the addition of APS, for the preparation of MCM-41. NH2-(CH3)MCM-41: The surface hydroxyl groups of NH2-MCM-41 were capped by post-modification with Si(CH3)3 groups under nitrogen atmosphere. Typically, 1 g of NH2-MCM-41 was suspended in a degassed solution of trimethylmethoxysilane (2 mL) in 50 mL of anhydrous toluene and then stirred at 110 °C for 24 h. After cooling to the ambient temperature, the solid was filtered and washed with toluene for three times and CH2Cl2 for the last time, and dried at 60 °C in vacuum for 24 h. 2-Imine Pyridine grafting MCM-41 (ImPy-MCM-41) and ImPy-(CH3)MCM-41: ImPy-MCM-41/ImPy-(CH3)MCM-41 was prepared by grafting NH2-MCM-41/NH2-(CH3)MCM-41 with 2-pyridinecarboxaldehyde under nitrogen atmosphere. NH2-MCM-41 (3 g) was added into a solution of 2-pyridinecarboxaldehyde (4.8 mmol, 0.514 g) in 50 mL of anhydrous methanol. The mixture was stirred at 60 °C for 12 h [50]. After cooling to the ambient temperature, the solid was filtered and washed thoroughly with ethanol till the filtrate was colorless to remove excess 2-pyridinecarboxaldehyde. The light yellow powder was dried overnight at 60 °C. ImPy-(CH3)MCM-41 was prepared by the addition of 1 g of NH2-(CH3)MCM-41 into a solution of 2-pyridinecarboxaldehyde (1.6 mmol, 0.171 g) in 20 mL of anhydrous methanol, following the same procedures as used for the preparation of ImPy-MCM-41. Cu-ImPy-MCM-41, Cu-ImPy-(CH3)MCM-41, Pd-ImPy-MCM-41, Cu/Pd-ImPy-MCM-41, and Cu/Pd-NH2-MCM-41: Cu-ImPy-MCM-41/Cu-ImPy-(CH3)MCM-41 was prepared by coordinating CuCl2 onto ImPy-MCM-41/ImPy-(CH3)MCM-41 following a published method [50,51]. 2 g of ImPy-MCM-41/ImPy-(CH3)MCM-41 was suspended in 30 mL anhydrous ethanol solution of CuCl2·2H2O (1.574 mmol, 0.2683 g) and then stirred at 40 °C for 12 h. The mixture was filtered, washed with ethanol for 5 times and dried at 80 °C for 12 h. Similar procedure was used, except replacing CuCl2·2H2O with 0.207 mmol of PdCl2, for the preparation of Pd-ImPy-MCM-41. Cu/Pd-ImPy-MCM-41 was prepared by coordinating CuCl2 and PdCl2 onto ImPy-MCM-41. 2 g of ImPy-MCM-41 was suspended in 30 mL of anhydrous ethanol solution of CuCl2·2H2O (1.574 mmol, 0.2683 g) and PdCl2 (0.188 mmol, 0.020 g), and then stirred at 40 °C for 12 h. The mixture was filtered, washed with ethanol for 5 times and dried at 80 °C for 12 h. For comparison, Cu/Pd-NH2-MCM-41 was also prepared by coordinating CuCl2 and PdCl2 onto NH2-MCM-41. Typically, 2 g of NH2-MCM-41 was suspended in 30 mL of anhydrous ethanol solution containing CuCl2·2H2O (1.574 mmol, 0.2683 g) and PdCl2 (0.188 mmol, 0.020 g), and then stirred at 40 °C for 12 h. The mixture was filtered, washed with ethanol for 5 times and dried at 80 °C for 12 h. Cu-Pd-ImPy-MCM-41, Pd-Cu-ImPy-MCM-41, and Pd-Cu-ImPy-(CH3)MCM-41: Cu-Pd-ImPy-MCM-41 was prepared by coordinating CuCl2 onto Pd-ImPy-MCM-41. 2 g of Pd-ImPy-MCM-41 was suspended in 30 mL of anhydrous ethanol solution of CuCl2·2H2O (1.574 mmol, 0.2683 g) and then stirred at 40 °C for 12 h. The mixture was filtered, washed with ethanol for 5 times and dried at 80 °C for 12 h. Pd-Cu-ImPy-MCM-41/Pd-Cu-ImPy-(CH3)MCM-41 was prepared by coordinating PdCl2 onto Cu-ImPy-MCM-41/Cu-ImPy-(CH3)MCM-41. Typically, 2 g of Cu-ImPy-MCM-41 or Cu-ImPy-(CH3)MCM-41 was suspended in 30 mL of anhydrous ethanol solution of PdCl2 (0.207 mmol, 0.0220 g) and then stirred at 40 °C for 12 h. The mixture was filtered, washed with ethanol for 5 times and dried at 80 °C for 12 h. The Pd-Cu-ImPy-MCM-41 with an input Cu/Pd molar ratio of 13.5/1, 10/1, 6/1, 4/1, or 2.5/1 was prepared in similar procedure by tailoring the input dosage of PdCl2. 2.3 Characterization Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were recorded on a Bruker V80 diffractometer using Cu Kα monochromatized radiation (λ = 0.1541 nm) with a scanning angle (2θ) range of 0.5°–7°. The quantitative analysis for Cu and Pd was performed on a Shimadzu ICPS-7500 inductively coupled plasma emission spectrometer (ICP-ES). Prior to characterization, 20 mg of the sample was calcined at 550 °C for 5 h under ambient atmosphere with a heating rate of 5 °C min−1 to remove the organic compounds. Then the calcined sample was dissolved into a 5 mL of dilute hydrofluoric acid at 60 °C. The solution was transferred to a 10 mL volumetric flask and diluted to 10 mL with deionized water. Nitrogen adsorption/desorption isotherms were measured on a micromeritics ASAP 2460 system. Prior to characterization, 0.1 g sample was outgassed at 120 °C for 6 h. The specific surface area was calculated by the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) method and the pore size distribution was calculated from desorption isotherm branch using Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) method. Quantitation of C, H, and N element was performed on avario MICRO cube elemental analyzer (Elementar). The grafting density was calculated as follows: (1) G r a f t i n g d e n s i t y ( n m - 2 ) = N c o n t e n t × 10 - 3 × N A S B E T × 10 18 , where, N content (mmol∙g−1) is determined by elemental analysis, NA is Avogadro's constant, SBET (m2∙g−1) is the specific surface area. Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectra were recorded on an iS50FT-IR (NICOLET) spectrometer equipped with BaF2 windows and a mercury-cadmium-telluride (MCT) detector cooled by liquid nitrogen with a resolution of 1 cm−1 and 64 scans in the range 840–4000 cm−1. About 15 mg of the sample was pressed into a self-supporting wafer and loaded into the IR cell. High resolution transmission electron microscopic (HRTEM) images and high-angle annular dark field (HAADF) images were taken on a Tecnai G2 F20 S-TWIN transmission electron microscope operated at 200 kV accelerating voltage. Energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDX) elemental analysis (mapping) were taken in scanning transmission electron microscopic (STEM) mode. The sample was dispersed in absolute ethanol under ultrasonic condition before deposition on a Mo microgrid. UV–visible diffuse reflectance spectra (UV–Vis DRS) were recorded on a Shimadzu UV-2600 spectrophotometer with an integrating sphere attachment using BaSO4 as the background standard. Solid state 29Si magic-angle spinning nuclear magnetic resonance (MAS NMR) analysis was carried out on a Bruker Avance 300 MHz solid-state spectrometer with a commercial 4 mm MAS NMR probe at frequencies of 59.6 MHz with kaolinite as standard reference for chemical shift. The X-ray photoelectron spectra (XPS) were recorded on a Shimadzu KRATOS AXIS SUPRAX-ray photoelectron spectroscope equipped with a monochromated Al-K X-ray source (1486.6 eV) at a pass energy of 40 eV. C1s peak at 284.8 eV was used as a calibration peak. In situ diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectra (DRIFTS) were recorded on an iS50FT-IR (NICOLET) spectrometer equipped with BaF2 windows and a Mercury-Cadmium-Telluride (MCT) detector, with a resolution of 4 cm−1 and 64 scans. The sample was first filled in the in-situ DRIFTS cell and pre-treated under Ar flow (10 mL∙min−1) at 130 °C for 30 min and cooled in Ar to 30 °C. Before ethanol adsorption, the spectrum for background was recorded at 30 °C. Ethanol was bubbled into the cell by Ar flow (10 mL∙min−1) until equilibrium was reached, and then the adsorbed ethanol was purged under Ar flow (10 mL∙min−1) until the spectra showed no change, and the spectrum was recorded. For competitive adsorption of CO and ethanol, the background spectrum was collected at 30 °C. Ethanol was bubbled into the cell by Ar flow (10 mL∙min−1) until equilibrium was reached, and then the adsorbed ethanol was desorbed under CO flow (10 mL∙min−1) for 20 min followed by Ar flow (10 mL∙min−1) purging. For ethanol adsorption under different atmosphere, the background spectrum was collected at 130 °C under Ar flow. Ethanol was bubbled into the cell by Ar flow (10 mL∙min−1), CO flow (10 mL∙min−1), O2 flow (10 mL∙min−1), or CO and O2 flow (8 mL∙min−1 for CO and 2 mL∙min−1 for O2) for 15 min, and then the adsorbed ethanol was desorbed under the same atmosphere, and the spectrum was recorded. For operando DRIFTS of ethanol oxycarbonylation, the background spectrum was collected at 130 °C under Ar flow. Ethanol was bubbled into the cell by Ar flow (10 mL∙min−1) until equilibrium was reached, and the adsorbed ethanol was purged with CO flow (10 mL∙min−1) for 10 min and then with CO and O2 flow (8 mL∙min−1 for CO and 2 mL∙min−1 for O2). The spectra were collected under CO and O2 flow. 2.4 Catalytic tests The catalytic test was performed with a fixed-bed reactor with a stainless steel tubular reactor of 8 mm inner diameter. 350 mg of catalyst (20–40 mesh) was loaded into the reactor. The remaining volume of the reactor tube was filled with quartz sand (20–40 mesh). Before being exposed to reactants, the catalyst was heated to 130 °C at 5 °C/min and remained at 130 °C for 30 min in a stream of high-purity N2. Then the system was pressurized to 1.5 MPa with CO and O2 (CO/O2 = 80/7, total flow rate is 87 mL/min). Ethanol (99.5 wt%) was pumped using a high-performance liquid chromatography pump at 50 μL∙min−1 and mixed with the flow of CO and O2 after evaporating in the evaporator. The reaction conditions were steadily kept at a reaction temperature of 130 °C and a reaction pressure of 1.5 MPa. The products were analyzed online by gas chromatograph (Shimadzu, GC-2014C) equipped with a HP-INOWAX capillary column and connected with a flame ionization detector (FID). Ethanol conversion (Conv.), product selectivity, space–time conversion rate of ethanol (STC), and space–time yield of DEC (STY) were calculated according to the following equations: (2) C o n v . % = F i n - F o u t F i n × 100 , (3) S e l . ( % ) = x × n i ∑ i × n i × 100 , (4) S T C m g ∙ g - 1 ∙ h - 1 = F i n × C o n v . × C b a l a n c e / M e t h a n o l / m C a t . , (5) a n d S T Y m g ∙ g - 1 ∙ h - 1 = S T C × M D E C 2 M E t O H × S e l . D E C , where Fin and Fout are the moles of input ethanol and unreacted ethanol, ni is the molar fraction of product i, x is the number of ethanol required to produce the product i, and mCat is the weight of catalyst. Calculations of mass transfer limitations were carried out using the Mears and Weisz-Prater analyses (see Supporting Information for detailed calculation) [52,53]. The calculations suggest the absence of diffusion limitation in this work. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Coordination of Cu(II) and/or Pd(II) to MCM-41 NH2-MCM-41 was first prepared in this work as a start-up for the coordination of Cu (II) and/or Pd (II). In the 29Si MAS NMR spectrum (Fig. 1 A), NH2-MCM-41 demonstrates two sets of broad signals attributed to the resonances for organosiloxane (Tm = RSi(OSi)m(OH)3-m, m = 1–3, −50 to −80 ppm) and for siloxane (Qn = Si(OSi)n(OH)4-n, n = 2–4, −90 to −120 ppm) units. The presence of Tm units provides an evidence for C-Si covalent bonds. In the powder X-ray diffraction pattern (Fig. 1 B), NH2-MCM-41 (Fig. 1 B, a) shows typical 100, 110, and 200 reflections with a spacing of 4.18, 2.43, and 2.00 nm in low-angle diffraction region (2 θ < 10°), which can be assigned to a well-ordered hexagonal symmetry lattice. In the grafting of 2-pyridinecarboxaldehyde and followed coordination of Cu (II) and/or Pd (II), the hexagonally ordered structures are well retained (Fig. 1 B, b-g). NH2-MCM-41, ImPy-MCM-41, and Cu (II) and/or Pd (II) coordinated ImPy-MCM-41, all exhibit typical type IV adsorption–desorption isotherms (Fig. 1 C), with a uniform pore size distribution at a maximum of 2.60–2.75 nm and surface area of above 710 m2 g−1. The well-ordered hexagonally symmetric structures for Cu (II) and/or Pd (II) coordinated ImPy-MCM-41 are fully confirmed by the TEM images (Fig. 1 D). The N grafting density in NH2-MCM-41 and ImPy-MCM-41 was determined to be 0.64 nm−2 and 0.66 nm−2. According to ICP determination, Cu loading is 3.4 wt% for Cu-ImPy-MCM-41, and Pd loading is 0.94 wt% for Pd-ImPy-MCM-41. Cu loading is determined as being 3.2 wt% in each case whether Cu and Pd are coordinated simultaneously (Cu/Pd -ImPy-MCM-41), Pd is coordinated prior to Cu (Cu-Pd-ImPy-MCM-41), or Cu is coordinated prior to Pd (Pd-Cu-ImPy-MCM-41), and Pd loading is 0.89 wt% for Cu/Pd-ImPy-MCM-41 (3.2% Cu/0.89% Pd-ImPy-MCM-41), 0.87 wt% for Cu-Pd-ImPy-MCM-41 (3.2% Cu-0.87% Pd-ImPy-MCM-41), and 0.86 for Pd-Cu-ImPy-MCM-41 (0.86% Pd-3.2% Cu-ImPy-MCM-41). The Cu/Pd molar ratio is calculated as 6.0. In the FT-IR spectra (Fig. 1 E), NH2-MCM-41 shows the bands at 3366 and 3307 cm−1 assigned [54] to ν(N-H) of -NH2 and the band at 1595 cm−1 assigned [54] to δ(N-H) of -NH2 (Fig. 1 E, a). After grafting of 2-pyridinecarboxaldehyde, the bands for ν(N-H) of -NH2 vanish and the band at 1651 cm−1 assigned [51,54] to ν(C = N) of imine, the bands at 1595 and 1475 cm−1 assigned [55] to ν(C = N) of pyridine ring, the band at 1572 cm−1 assigned [56] to ν(C = C) of pyridine ring, and the band at 1444 cm−1 assigned [51,54] to δ(C-H) of -CH2- adjacent to imine are observed (Fig. 1 E, b), indicative of the complete conversion of amino to pyridine-imine. The following coordination of Pd (II) onto ImPy-MCM-41 results in no visible change of the IR absorption (Fig. 1 E, c). But the coordination of Cu (II) onto ImPy-MCM-41 (Fig. 1 E, d) causes the band for ν(C = N) of imine shift from 1651 cm−1 to 1646 cm−1 while the bands for ν(C = N) of pyridine ring to shift from 1595 and 1475 cm−1 to 1603 and 1481 cm−1, respectively. Also, the band for δ(C-H) of methylene bonded to imine blue shifts from 1441 cm−1 to 1449 cm−1. These results indicate the involvement of C = N bond of imine and nitrogen atom of pyridine ring in the coordination sphere of Cu (II). The results observed for Cu/Pd-ImPy-MCM-41 (Fig. 1 E, e), Cu-Pd-ImPy-MCM-41 (Fig. 1 E, f), and Pd-Cu-ImPy-MCM-41 (Fig. 1 E, g) are similar to that for Cu-ImPy-MCM-41, no matter what is the coordination sequence. In the UV–Vis spectra (Fig. 1 F), ImPy-MCM-41 shows two absorption bands at 233 and 270 nm (Fig. 1 F, a), which are attributed[57] to π → π* and n → π* transition of the pyridine imine ligand. The emission intensity gets weaker after the coordination of Pd (II) (Fig. 1 F, b), due to the increase of rigidity caused by the coordination between Pd (II) and pyridine-imine ligand. The transition band of n → π* red shifts from 270 to 283 nm and a new band at 390 nm, as a fact of the ligand to metal charge transfer (LMCT) interactions[51], is observed for Cu-ImPy-MCM-41 (Fig. 1 F, c), demonstrating the coordination between Cu (II) and pyridine imine ligand. Also, the emission intensity of the band at 233 nm becomes weaker on account of the increase of rigidity after coordination. Similar results are observed for Cu/Pd-ImPy-MCM-41 (Fig. 1 F, d), Cu-Pd-ImPy-MCM-41 (Fig. 1 F, e), and Pd-Cu-ImPy-MCM-41 (Fig. 1 F, f). The FT-IR and UV–Vis results indicate that both of Cu (II) and Pd (II) could be coordinated onto the pyridine imine ligand on the surface of ImPy-MCM-41, and the coordination of Cu (II) to pyridine imine is stronger than that of Pd (II). 3.2 Distribution of coordinated Cu and Pd in the mesopores The distribution of coordinated Cu and Pd on ImPy-MCM-41 is investigated using element mapping technique. According to the STEM element mapping images (Fig. 2 ), Cu and Pd are either distributed along the surface of pore walls in a uniform pattern, but the relative distribution of Cu and Pd displays dependence on the coordination sequence. In each case, Cu sites are observed as being mainly adjacent to Pd sites (Cu-Pd pairs). But in the case that Pd is coordinated prior to Cu (Fig. 2, a), more Pd-Pd adjacences are observed than the case that Cu is coordinated prior to Pd (Fig. 2, b) or that Cu and Pd are coordinated simultaneously (Fig. 2, c). Then X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) is used to further elucidate the distribution of Cu and Pd (Fig. 3 ). In the Cu 2p XPS spectra, both of Cu 2p3/2 binding energies (B.E.) assigned [58–60] to Cu (II) and Cu (I) at 934.4 and 932.4 eV are observed. No signal for Cu (0) at 918.6 eV [61] in the Cu LMM spectrum is resolved (Fig. S1). The presence of Pd makes no effects on the binding energy of Cu (I) or Cu (II) but visibly decreases the area of Cu (II) XPS signals. In the Pd 3d XPS spectra, 343.5 and 338.0 eV assigned [62,63] to 3d3/2 and 3d5/2 of Pd (II), and 342.2 and 336.6 eV assigned [62,63] to 3d3/2 and 3d5/2 of Pd (0) are observed. The co-existence of Cu hardly influences the B.E. of Pd (II) and Pd (0) but increases the area of Pd (II) XPS signals. The presence of Cu (I) in Cu-ImPy-MCM-41 and the presence of Pd (0) in Pd-ImPy-MCM-41 could be attributed to the electron transfer from the C = N bond of imine and/or nitrogen atom of pyridine ring to Cu (II) and Pd (II) or self-disproportion. For Cu/Pd-ImPy-MCM-41, Cu-Pd-ImPy-MCM-41, or Pd-Cu-ImPy-MCM-4, with the co-existence of Cu and Pd, an increase in Cu (I) content while a decrease in Pd (0) content implies the electron transfer from Pd (0) to Cu (II) in Cu-Pd pairs. The percentages of Cu (I)/Cu (II) and Pd (II)/Pd (0) are quantatively estimated from the area of XPS signals (Table 1 ). The percentage of Cu (I) increases with decreasing Pd (0), confirming the electron transfer from Pd (0) to Cu (II) in Cu-Pd pairs, with more Cu (I) sites afforded. According to the higher percentage of Cu (I) and lower percentage Pd (0) (Table 1), better Cu-Pd pairs have been accomplished in Pd-Cu-ImPy-MCM-4, which has been prepared by the coordination of Cu (II) first and Pd (II) followed. 3.3 Oxycarbonylation of ethanol on Cu-Pd pairs The Cu (II) and/or Pd (II) coordinated ImPy-MCM-41 have then been applied in the oxycarbonylation of ethanol under 1.5 MPa at 130 °C (Table 2 ). An ethanol conversion of 1.1% with a selectivity of 63.9% to DEC is afforded on Cu-ImPy-MCM-41 (Table 2, Entry 1). Introducing Pd in either way not only increases the ethanol conversion but also promotes the DEC formation (Table 2, Entry 2–4 versus 1). It can be clearly seen that the selectivity to DEC and the STC of ethanol increase with the increase in Cu (I) content at a comparable ethanol conversion (2.8%-3.1%) (Table 2, Entry 2–4). A selectivity of 85.4% to DEC with 189 mg∙g−1∙h−1 STC of ethanol (3.1% of ethanol conversion) have been afforded on Pd-Cu-ImPy-MCM-41 (Table 2, Entry 4), in which Cu-Pd pairs are better formed. 1,1-Diethoxyethane (DEE) has been detected as the main competitive side-product, suggesting that CO insertion is the rate-limiting step in the ethanol oxycarbonylation. A selectivity of above 30% to DEE has been afforded on Cu-ImPy-MCM-41 (Table 2, Entry 1). Almost no oxycarbonylation products have been detected on Pd-ImPy-MCM-41 (Table 2, Entry 5), with a selectivity of 88.4% to DEE and a low conversion of ethanol (a conversion of 0.1% and STC of 8 mg∙g−1∙h−1). Cu-Pd pairs are able to inhibit the production of DEE (Table 2, Entry 2–4). Better-formed Cu-Pd pairs inhibit the formation of DEE more effectively (Table 2, Entry 4). No transformation of ethanol occurs on bare ImPy-MCM-41 (Table 2, Entry 6). The results indicate the vital role of Cu sites in the activation of ethanol and especially Cu-Pd pairs in the insertion of CO to the activated ethanol. On Cu/Pd-NH2-MCM-41 for comparison, a selectivity of 60.3% to DEC was obtained under an ethanol conversion of 1.0% (Table 2, Entry 7). Either of the conversion of ethanol or the STY of DEC on Cu/Pd-NH2-MCM-41 is similar to that on Cu-ImPy-MCM-41 (Table 2, Entry 1), indicative of the promotion of the coordination with the N sites in pyridine and imine. The hydroxyl groups of MCM-41 surface have also been capped by post-modification with Si(CH3)3 groups (Fig. 1 A, b). The post-modification makes no marked impact on the selectivity to DEC and the conversion of ethanol (Table 2, Entry 8) in the oxycarbonylation. The Cu/Pd molar ratio has also been tailored, with first increased from 6 to 13.5 and 10.0, and then decreased from 6 to 4.0 and 2.5, aiming to tailor the Cu-Pd pairs. As revealed by the XPS characterization (Table 1 , Entry 6–9), Pd (0) percentage increases with increasing Pd loading and decreasing Cu/Pd molar ratio, but Cu (I) percentage display a volcanic relation with Pd loading and Cu/Pd ratio. In the oxycarbonylation of ethanol (Table 2 , Entry 9–12), an increase in the STC of ethanol and STY of DEC is observed with increasing Cu (I) percentage. The selectivity to DEC first displays a rise and then remains unchanged with increasing Cu (I) percentage. The selectivity to DEE increases with decreasing Pd (0) percentage and increasing Pd (II) sites. The variations of ethanol STC and product selectivity with Cu (I) and Pd (0) percentages confirm the role of Cu (I) in the activation of ethanol and the role of Cu-Pd pairs in the CO insertion for the oxycarbonylation of ethanol. In the Pd-catalyzed oxycarbonylation of enallenols [64], the Pd (0) sites, generated by in situ reduction of CO, have been proposed to promote CO insertion due to the enhancement of CO adsorption on Pd (0). In the oxycarbonylation of ethanol here, Pd (0) clearly inhibits the formation of DEE, consistent with enhanced CO activation on Pd (0). But the selectivity to DEC is obviously independent of Pd (0) and sensitive to Cu/Pd molar ratio, indicating that the Cu-Pd pairs are more crucial for CO insertion. To understand the role of Cu and/or Pd sites in the oxycarbonylation of ethanol, FT-IR spectra of ethanol or CO adsorption/desorption on Cu-ImPy-MCM-41, Pd-ImPy-MCM-41, and Pd-Cu-ImPy-MCM-41 were recorded (Fig. 4 ). Ethanol adsorption occurs on either coordinated Cu or coordinated Pd sites at 30 °C (Fig. 4 A), presenting absorption bands around 2978, 2930, 2901, 1456, 1402, and 1266–1269 cm−1. According to previous reports [65–67], the bands at 2978, 2930, and 2901 cm−1 can be assigned to the stretching modes of -CH3 and -CH2 in un-dissociated ethanol, the bands at 1456 and 1402 cm−1 to the δ modes of -CH2 and -CH3 in un-dissociated ethanol, the band at 1266–1269 cm−1 to the δ modes of OH in adsorbed ethanol. The results provide evidences for that the ethanol adsorption on Pd, Cu, or Cu-Pd sites occurs through the oxygen lone pair, consistent with reported in literature [68]. The ethanol adsorption on coordinated Cu (Fig. 4 A, a), Pd (Fig. 4 A, b), or Cu-Pd (Fig. 4 A, c) sites displays no visible difference. The band intensity shows only a slight decrease in the desorption, indicative of a strong ethanol adsorption in each case and the activation of ethanol on either Cu or Pd sites. The adsorption of CO (Fig. 4 B) visibly occurs on Cu-ImPy-MCM-41, giving a band at 2095 cm−1 assigned [29–31] to the CO adsorbed on Cu (I) sites (Fig. 4 B, a). On Pd-ImPy-MCM-41, only a weak absorption is observed at 2042 cm−1 to the CO adsorbed on Pd (0) sites (Fig. 4 B, b). On Pd-Cu-ImPy-MCM-41, only the adsorption of CO on Cu (I) sites is observed (Fig. 4 B, b), similar to that on Cu-ImPy-MCM-41, indicating the adsorption of CO on Cu (I) sites is much stronger than on Pd (0) sites. According to the above FT-IR results (Fig. 4), it is clear that ethanol adsorption is much more strongly on Cu (I) sites than CO, indicative of the difficulty for CO insertion. Although Pd site itself (Pd (II)/Pd (0)) has the ability to activate ethanol, the activated ethanol has been conversed to DEE due to its lack of the ability to effectively activate CO. Then the CO adsorption/desorption following ethanol adsorption at 30 °C was performed on Cu-Pd pair (Fig. 5 ). The FT-IR spectra of ethanol adsorption were primarily recorded. The ethanol adsorption on 0.86%Pd-3.2%Cu-ImPy-MCM-41 (Fig. 5 A), 3.2%Cu-0.87%Pd-ImPy-MCM-41 (Fig. 5 B), and 3.2%Cu/0.89%Pd-ImPy-MCM-41 (Fig. 5 C) is similar, all presenting the absorption of CH2 and CH3 in un-dissociated ethanol at 2978, 2902, and 1402–1395 cm−1, the absorption of OH in adsorbed ethanol at 1266 cm−1, and the absorption of C-O stretching vibration [66] in adsorbed ethanol at 1066 cm−1. Then CO adsorption followed by desorption was performed. No changes for the bands of adsorbed ethanol is observed after CO adsorption while the absorption of CO adsorbed on Cu (I) site is observed at 2095 cm−1. That means Cu-Pd pairs have the ability to activate CO and ethanol simultaneously. The CO adsorption is very weak in that the absorption at 2095 cm−1 becomes more and more indistinct with desorption time. The intensity ratio of CO absorption (2095 or 2094 cm−1) to ethanol absorption (C-H stretching mode at 2978 cm−1) has been applied to estimate the ability of Cu (I) to adsorb CO (Fig. 5 D). Pd-Cu-ImPy-MCM-41 (Fig. 5 A), with better formed Cu-Pd pairs than either Cu-Pd-ImPy-MCM-41 (Fig. 5 B) or Cu/Pd -ImPy-MCM-41 (Fig. 5 C), is able to activate CO in higher population and stronger adsorption (Fig. 5 D), which accounts for its better selectivity to DEC. 3.4 Insights into the catalytic process By monitoring the reaction profile on Pd-Cu-ImPy-MCM-41 (Fig. 6 ), it can be seen that either the production of DEC or the conversion of ethanol shows an induction period. Over as-prepared Pd-Cu-ImPy-MCM-41 (Fig. 6 a), the selectivity to DEC and the STC of ethanol increase gradually in the initial 6 h. DEE is observed as the main product in the first 6 h, implying that CO insertion is the rate-controlling step in ethanol oxycarbonylation. Similar phenomena are observed on Cu/Pd-ImPy-MCM-41 and Cu-Pd-ImPy-MCM-41 (not shown here). So a pre-treatment on Pd-Cu-ImPy-MCM-41 was performed. The pre-treatment with CO (Fig. 6 b), ethanol (Fig. 6 c), or CO and ethanol (Fig. 6 d) all reduces the production of DEE. The inhibition of DEE is especially visible with CO involved in the pre-treatment (Fig. 6 b and d), indicating a promotion of CO insertion. As a result, the STC of ethanol at steady state, as well as the STY of DEC, has been visibly promoted (Table 2, Entry 13–15 versus Entry 4) with no any reduction of the selectivity to DEC. The promotion of STC and STY is more marked over the Pd-Cu-ImPy-MCM-41 pre-treated with CO or CO and ethanol. According to the quasi in-situ XPS results (Table 1, Entry 10–12), the pre-treatment with CO mainly increases the percentage of Cu (I) (Table 1, Entry 10 versus 5), the pre-treatment with ethanol mainly increases the percentage of Pd (0) (Table 1 , Entry 11 versus 5), and the pre-treatment stimutaneously with CO and ethanol increases both of Cu (I) and Pd (0) percentages, which well accounts for the improved conversion of ethanol to DEC. The FT-IR spectra of ethanol adsorption/desorption on Pd-Cu-ImPy-MCM-41 at 130 °C under varied atmosphere (Fig. 7 ) have been recorded to investigate the effects of O2. The absorption bands at 2981, 2935, 2903, 1443, 1397, 1266, and 1068 cm−1 assigned to un-dissociated adsorbed ethanol [66] are observed under Ar or CO atmosphere (Fig. 7 , a and b). Similar results are observed under O2 atmosphere except that the band at 1266 cm−1 for O-H decreases while a new band at 1717 cm−1 for C = O [67] of acetaldehyde is observed (Fig. 7 , c), indicative of the cleavage of O-H bond and the oxidation of adsorbed ethanol to acetaldehyde. A band at 1677 cm−1 assigned [29–31] to C = O of monoethoxycarbonate and a band at 1095 assigned to C-O-C stretching modes of monoethoxycarbonate are observed under CO and O2 atmosphere (Fig. 7 , d). Generally, a reduction-oxidation process would occur on the catalyst in oxidative carbonylation reactions and the oxidants oxidized the released metal species to finish the catalytic process [32]. Our results indicate that, besides the role of general reduction–oxidation process, O2 promotes the cleavage of O-H bond in ethanol. To get more insights into the catalysis, the operando DRIFTS spectra for ethanol oxycarbonylation are further recorded (Fig. 8 ). In addition to the bands at 2985–2900, 1396, and 1279 cm−1 assigned [66] to C-H of adsorbed ethanol and the band around 1714–1717 cm−1 assigned [67] to C = O of acetaldehyde, a new band around 1678–1680 cm−1 assigned [29–31] to C = O of monoethoxycarbonate is gradually observed on Cu/Pd-ImPy-MCM-41 (Fig. 8 A), Cu-Pd-ImPy-MCM-41 (Fig. 8 B), or Pd-Cu-ImPy-MCM-41 (Fig. 8 C). The absorption intensity of C = O for monoethoxycarbonate gradually increases with increasing introduction time of CO and O2, indicating the continuous oxycarbonylation of adsorbed ethanol. The intensity ratio of monoethoxycarbonate absorption (C = O at 1678 or 1680 cm−1) to ethanol absorption (C-H stretching mode at 1263–1279 cm−1) has been applied to represent the conversion of ethanol to DEC (Fig. 8 D). The increase in 1680 cm−1 absorption is more obvious on Pd-Cu-ImPy-MCM-41 than on or Cu-Pd-ImPy-MCM-41 and especially on Cu/Pd-ImPy-MCM-41 (Fig. 8 D). But all Cu/Pd-ImPy-MCM-41, Cu-Pd-ImPy-MCM-41, and Pd-Cu-ImPy-MCM-41 display faster oxycarbonylation than Cu-ImPy-MCM-41, indicative of the vital role of Cu-Pd pairs. 4 Conclusions In summary, a highly effective heterogeneous catalysis has been achieved for the oxycarbonylation of ethanol to DEC with Cu and Pd coordinated onto N-containing ligand on the surface of mesoporous MCM-41. Cu-Pd pairs have been better built by manipulating the coordination sequence of Cu (II) and Pd (II). A STY of up to 207 mg∙g−1∙h−1 of DEC with a selectivity of 85.4% to DEC has been achieved on well-formed Cu-Pd pairs. The contribution of Cu-Pd pairs to the oxycarbonylation of ethanol originates from the generated Cu (I) and Pd (0) sites. Pre-treatment with CO and/or ethanol increases the percentages of Cu (I) and Pd (0) sites, thus promoting oxycarbonylation of ethanol. A STY of 325 mg∙g−1∙h−1 for DEC has been achieved on pre-activated 0.86%Pd-3.2%Cu-ImPy-MCM-41 stimutaneously with ethanol and CO. It should be noted that the yield of DEC deserves to be further improved, which could be achieved by regulating Cu sites to monovalent copper oxides or Cu nanoparticles. coredata.dc:description: Oxidative carbonylation has attracted broad interest from both academia and industry in recent years. Oxycarbonylation of ethanol to diethyl carbonate (DEC) has been of great challenge due to the difficulty in the simultaneous activation of ethanol and CO. This work reports a heterogeneous Cu-Pd pair catalysis for simultaneous activation of ethanol and CO, affording a selectivity of 85.4% to DEC and a space–time yield (STY) of up to 207 mg∙g−1∙h−1. Well distributed Cu-Pd pair affords more Cu (I) sites, promoting CO activation and the followed insertion to adsorbed ethanol. Further increasing ratio of Cu (I) species via the pre-treatment of catalyst with CO and ethanol promotes simultaneously the activation of ethanol and CO, affording a STY of 325 mg∙g−1∙h−1 of DEC.
coredata.dc:title: Cu-Pd pair facilitated simultaneous activation of ethanol and CO
